intro: Ossaea turquinensis, commonly known as the Turquin's ossaea, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to withstand harsh, dry conditions. Its leaves are finely divided and often covered in a dense layer of fine hairs, which help reduce water loss. Ossaea turquinensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique adaptations and potential ecological significance in its native habitat.
